a:11:{s:3:"key";s:19:"field_589804afa804d";s:5:"label";s:14:"Introduce Text";s:4:"name";s:14:"introduce_text";s:4:"type";s:7:"wysiwyg";s:12:"instructions";s:0:"";s:8:"required";s:1:"0";s:13:"default_value";s:1199:"By now, each of us have completed various training programs at Aesop.
This training will be different.
The purpose of undertaking this course is to prepare us for the imminent launch of 2017’s major campaign – Skin Care Platform.
All Aesop employees, worldwide, will be completing this training at their own pace.
This training will consolidate Aesop’s philosophy on skin care, refine our communication on seasonal change and retailing, and hopefully, foster a united sense of renewed energy on the topic.
This advanced training will take place in three sessions, each composed of about 30 minutes. To begin, we will discuss the skin physiology.
At Aesop our skin lexicon, while informed, is purposefully limited. This is because consultations with customers often do not require scientific expressions, merely the base knowledge necessary to shape understanding on why skin care is important.
Today we broaden this lexicon. The material can be scientific at times, and this may seem unnecessary, however our purpose is to allow all of us to understand why Aesop skin care is unique, and allow us to continue to sell our products with engagement, education and confidence.";s:7:"toolbar";s:4:"full";s:12:"media_upload";s:3:"yes";s:17:"conditional_logic";a:3:{s:6:"status";s:1:"0";s:5:"rules";a:1:{i:0;a:2:{s:5:"field";s:4:"null";s:8:"operator";s:2:"==";}}s:8:"allorany";s:3:"all";}s:8:"order_no";i:8;}

a:11:{s:3:"key";s:19:"field_589beeeb5eea9";s:5:"label";s:21:"Welcome Mail Template";s:4:"name";s:21:"welcome_mail_template";s:4:"type";s:7:"wysiwyg";s:12:"instructions";s:24:"Variables: {{user_name}}";s:8:"required";s:1:"0";s:13:"default_value";s:1065:"Welcome {{first_name}} to Chapters on Skin. This training is delivered in three parts.
Chapter One, The Fundamentals of Skin is foundational learning. The content in this chapter is instrumental to Chapters Two and Three, hence, must be completed successfully before advancing.
In this chapter, the anatomy and physiology of the skin is presented. We look at the different layers of the skin, and also reflect upon Aesop’s skin care history.
Chapter Two, Collected Stories: Time and Sunlight explores what happens to skin over time, and when under the duress of sunlight. We urge you to undertake this chapter with two weeks’ of completing Chapter One, and this will ensure your awareness is pliant to the final phase.
Chapter Three, Skin in Flux, considers the skin as it is when it is subject to change. The effects of urban living and seasonal change on the skin are some of the themes explored within this chapter. We encourage all staff to use this material to inform Aesop customers, and also to refine our own patterns of Aesop skin care use.";s:7:"toolbar";s:4:"full";s:12:"media_upload";s:3:"yes";s:17:"conditional_logic";a:3:{s:6:"status";s:1:"0";s:5:"rules";a:1:{i:0;a:3:{s:5:"field";s:19:"field_589bf1723cf51";s:8:"operator";s:2:"==";s:5:"value";s:1:"1";}}s:8:"allorany";s:3:"all";}s:8:"order_no";i:25;}

Someone has requested a password reset for the following account: {{site_url}} Email: {{email}} If this was a mistake, just ignore this email and nothing will happen. To reset your password, visit the following address: {{reset_password_url}}

Welcome {{first_name}} to Chapters on Skin. This training is delivered in three parts. Chapter One, The Fundamentals of Skin is foundational learning. The content in this chapter is instrumental to Chapters Two and Three, hence, must be completed successfully before advancing. In this chapter, the anatomy and physiology of the skin is presented. We look at the different layers of the skin, and also reflect upon Aesop’s skin care history. Chapter Two, Collected Stories: Time and Sunlight explores what happens to skin over time, and when under the duress of sunlight. We urge you to undertake this chapter with two weeks’ of completing Chapter One, and this will ensure your awareness is pliant to the final phase. Chapter Three, Skin in Flux, considers the skin as it is when it is subject to change. The effects of urban living and seasonal change on the skin are some of the themes explored within this chapter. We encourage all staff to use this material to inform Aesop customers, and also to refine our own patterns of Aesop skin care use.

item.title: Skin In Flux
item.dc:creator: sc-admin
item.content:encoded: In this third and final chapter, we will consolidate the foundational learning from the previous two chapters, and consider the skin as it is when it is subject to change, or more simply, in flux. Our intent is to make the learning offered useful to the store environment, and to address many of the topics our customers ask of us every day. How does seasonal change affect my skin? What role do topically applied vitamins play in protecting the skin? This chapter will address these questions, as well as delving more deeply into free radicals and anti-oxidants. At Aesop the concept of seasonal change is central to the way we prescribe skin care, but why?

Chapters on Skin
[get-my-courses]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: By now, each of us have completed various training programs at Aesop. This training will be different. The purpose of undertaking this course is to prepare us for the imminent launch of 2017’s major campaign – Skin Care Platform. All Aesop employees, worldwide, will be completing this training at their own pace. This training will consolidate Aesop’s philosophy on skin care, refine our communication on seasonal change and retailing, and hopefully, foster a united sense of renewed energy on the topic. This advanced training will take place in three sessions, each composed of about 30 minutes. To begin, we will discuss the skin physiology. At Aesop our skin lexicon, while informed, is purposefully limited. This is because consultations with customers often do not require scientific expressions, merely the base knowledge necessary to shape understanding on why skin care is important. Today we broaden this lexicon. The material can be scientific at times, and this may seem unnecessary, however our purpose is to allow all of us to understand why Aesop skin care is unique, and allow us to continue to sell our products with engagement, education and confidence.
Great progress {{curUser.first_name}}, keep up the momentum
Send a link to reset password
Please check your email for a link to reset your password
Password or Confirm Password is empty

Healthy, glowing skin is the by-product of a balanced lifestyle, careful cleansing, and appropriate hydration. Genetic and hormonal factors also play a role in skin's appearance, as do climate and pollution, which means that choosing the right skin care products requires careful consideration.

item.title: Questions and answers for Collected Stories: Time and Sunlight
item.dc:creator: sc-admin

item.title: Questions and answers for Skin in Flux
item.dc:creator: sc-admin
item.content:encoded: To conclude, there is one final quiz to assess your understanding of the material.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
[skincare_topic_photo image="913"][/skincare_topic_photo] [skincare_topic_photo image="914"][/skincare_topic_photo] [skincare_topic_photo image="683"][/skincare_topic_photo] Hormonal changes during this period impact the skin; perhaps more so than at any other time in our lives. There is a surge of hormones (primarily testosterone) for both males and females which can lead to the onset of acne. A combination of increased oil production, stimulation of sweat and oil glands, as well as thickening of the skin all lead to a higher propensity to clogged pores and congestion. We recommend deep and thorough cleansing with products such as Amazing Face Cleanser (daily) and Chamomile Concentrate Anti-Blemish Masque (twice weekly) to help remove excess oil and keep the skin as clean as possible in combination with Bitter Orange Astringent Toner; the only toner in the Aesop range that actively assists in the oil removal process thanks to the inclusion of Alcohol Denat. This should be followed by light and soothing hydration to seal the skin and combat potential inflammation associated with excess oil production and would confidently recommend Lightweight Facial Hydrating Serum in this case. Control may be applied onto to spots and blemishes to both calm and speed away the spot.

Hormones and their effect on the skin, from adolescence through to adulthood

[skincare_topic_photo image="930"]การเปลี่ยนแปลงของระดับฮอร์โมนของเพศหญิงในช่วงการเป็นประจำเดือน แผนภูมินี้แสดงถึงความผันแปรของฮอร์โมนทั้งสองชนิดและทำไมผิวถึงจะมีโอกาสที่จะถูกเร้าได้ง่ายในช่วงระยะเวลาสั้นๆ [/skincare_topic_photo] Oestrogen, which is present in at varying levels in both males and females, has a number of positive effects on the skin, primarily;
  • Increased collagen synthesis – the skin is strong, supple and resilient, heals quickly.
  • Decreased oil production – sebum is regulated, tendency for blemishes reduced.
  • General decrease in inflammation – overall calmness and lack of reactivity.
  • Increased Hyaluronic Acid production – the skin is well hydrated, plump and soft.
Oestrogen levels peak in the twenties, a period during which skin has the luminosity and plumpness we associate with 'youth'. However, the abundance of circulating oestrogen can have a downside, namely the dip that then occurs during the menstrual cycle (see hormone level graph). Ordinarily oestrogen can temper the oil increasing effect of its counterpart hormone testosterone. Yet as oestrogen levels drop in the week or so leading to menstruation this effect is subdued and the now prominent testosterone runs wild exerting its effect, leading to increased tendency to congestion and breakouts. During this time, it is important not to over-strip the skin, which will exacerbate oil production. Instead, we suggest products that gently and efficiently lift excess oil, while also calming associated inflammation.
Skin and the Poetics of Time

Climate is ever-changing, unpredictable, and often more complicated than ‘summer’ and ‘winter’.
Some parts of the world experience distinct seasons, and may encounter varying temperatures ranging from hot to cold. Other regions may enjoy consistent temperatures throughout the year, but still experience changes in humidity levels and rainfall. A general awareness of the world’s weather patterns is important.
In store, the concept of seasonal change is one which must be introduced from the very first consultation with new customers. It should then be discussed during all subsequent consultations with skin care clients.
Climate controlled environments must also be considered when prescribing products, regardless of outside temperatures.
The same way we change our wardrobe to suit the seasons, we should adapt our skin care too. In the cooler months we tend to wear more layers; a woollen jumper, coat, scarf and hat. Similarly, our skin during this time requires more hydration to counter the drying effects of the climate. This is why we recommend cleansing with more gentle formulations, layering hydration with nourishing toners, and blending oils with creams to boost hydration.
In summer the skin calls for more thorough cleansing, astringent toners and lighter hydration.
This approach is part of why we offer size variations and commonly recommend the smaller size for seasonal duration only. This way customers’ changing needs are accommodated, and an invitation to return at the break of the next season remains at the forefront of consultations.

Skin Macrostructure

Skin varies in thickness, based on anatomical location and function. At the most delicate, on the eyelids, it can be as fine as 0.5 mm, or about the same thickness as a piece of paper. The soles of the feet are typically the thickest areas of skin, about 1.5 – 2 mm. Thicker skin tends to be stronger in order to facilitate the impact of repeated manipulation and locomotion demanded of it. Think about the palms and soles of feet, elbows, knees and flexor surfaces, and the fingers and toes. Thinner skin, although still remarkably strong, functions across a broader or more general scope and covers the greater part of the body. [skincare_topic_photo image="672"][/skincare_topic_photo] Did you know? Lips do not contain their own discrete or rich supply of blood vessels. Their colour comes from the fact that their layers develop differently and do not normally become cornified, or toughened, like regular skin.  Lips are therefore translucent, unlike the surrounding skin, and effectively act as a window to the underlying tissues.

Skin Microstructure

[skincare_topic_photo image="827"][/skincare_topic_photo] The skin is comprised of three layers. However, this categorisation is too simplistic. It is best to consider the skin as a system, whereby one layer cannot be affected without some effect being subject on another.
  1. Epidermis. The outermost and thinnest layer of the skin.
  2. Dermis. A thicker supportive layer. This is where the collagen fibres live, representing about 70% of this layer.
  3. Hypodermis. This is also known as the subcutaneous tissue, or subcutis. The underlying support layer where the fat tissues are stored.
A note about where our products act: Generally speaking, Aesop products, and our language around skin care, tends to focus on surface effects, meaning that while some small molecules of our formulas may be able to traverse the skin and reach the Dermis, generally we are confined to being effective only on the Epidermis.

The Epidermis is the layer which protects the body by shielding it from ultraviolet (UV) radiation through sunlight, heat and cold, liquids (preventing their excessive absorption), and external substances and toxins. Although it is classified as one layer, it is composed of five sub layers, and perhaps more importantly, a coating or barrier. The Hydrolipidic Film is a protective barrier that covers the entire surface of the skin. It is the first barrier of the skin against harmful bacteria and agressive attack. If the skin is over cleansed, the hydrolipidic film will be reduced, resulting in loss of hydration. Likewise, lipid levels can vary with seasonal change. This layer to the skin has a responsive and dynamic nature, and is closely linked to environmental factors. In general, the epidermis allows for the protective and retentive roles of the skin. It is made up of:
  1. Sweat, which in itself is made up of water, mineral salt and organic acid (lactic acid is one example)
  2. Sebaceous lipids (sebum, fatty acid and other lipids)
  3. Peptides and Amino-Acids
  4. Good bacteria, i.e. those needed to maintain good skin health

Emollients

These substances are lipid based. They feed the lipid environment of the stratum corneum, and help prevent water loss in a passive manner. They smooth, soften and protect the uppermost layer of the skin. Examples include; Vegetable and Nut Oils (Wheatgerm Oil, Sweet Almond Oil), Butters (Shea Butter, Cocoa Butter), Fatty Acids (Oleic Acid, Linoleic Acids) and Emollient Esters (Coco-Caprylate, Ethyhexyl Olivate). They help to prevent flakiness and skin dryness by keeping the ‘mortar’ intact and barrier integrity maintained.

Humectants

They are hygroscopic molecules working that attract, bind and trap water (a little like a sponge. They exist naturally in the skin and form part of the skin’s ‘Natural Moisturising Factor’ (NMF). Examples include; Glycerine, Amino acids, Sodium Lactate, Simple Polysaccharide (such as Hyaluronic Acid). Used to redress / prevent dehydration and improve moisture of the skin. We can also use film-forming ingredients to reinforce the hydrolipidic film and help reduce TEWL, which in turn increase overall hydration level. Examples include; Biosaccharide Gum-1, High Molecular Weight Hyaluronic Acid and Sodium Carrageenan

[skincare_topic_photo image="687"][/skincare_topic_photo]
Skin care was the third category we introduced after hair care and body care, but these all had their origins from a common principle that still applies – the care for the health of the skin. We urge clients to nurture and protect their skin, regardless of age. For more mature skin, which can be prone to dryness, we recommend the use of our richly hydrating, anti-oxidant and vitamin-rich creams, oils and treatments. We also encourage our clients not to buy into the notion that signs of passing time are a bad thing: in evolved cultures, maturity is equated with wisdom. By keeping the skin carefully cleansed, occasionally exfoliated, and adequately nourished and hydrated it is possible to help skin appear and perform at its best. In considering the hair care range, it was always about the care of the scalp, and facial skin care was a natural extension of that. Treating the health of the skin with respect and addressing the needs of different types of skin. The gradients of cleansing and hydration requirements differs both by skin type, condition and location. The skin on our hands or our lips need different levels of hydration to our face and scalp. A fascination with botanical ingredients and essential oils, and the benefits these can bring to our formulations, along with a considered approach that every ingredient used must be serving a purpose has remained consistent. In 1992, Aesop released our first facial skin care product, Purifying Facial Cream Cleanser: a one-step skin cleanser and makeup remover. This product was, and still is, a perfected, water-soluble cleansing cream for dry, very dry and sensitive skins. Universally applicable, it is also suited to normal and combination (with a tendency to dry) skin in winter. This cream formulation is infused with anti-oxidant botanicals and is free of mineral oils. At the time of release, this product was inimitable, and created a path for us to continue to develop skin care of the highest quality.

[skincare_topic_photo image="605"][/skincare_topic_photo]
The skin is our largest organ, representing close to ten per cent of our total body mass. Skin cells are in a constant state of renewal, one new skin is produced every 25 to 45 days. Because of this, we lose about three grams of skin cells per day, or one kilogram each year. In essence, skin is composed of more than 70 per cent water. The high water level of the skin, and that fact that we continually lose water via trans-epidermal water loss (TEWL), is what presents the need to confer plentiful hydration to the skin.

[skincare_topic_photo image="694"][/skincare_topic_photo] The Stratum Corneum is arguably the most important layer, and the one which is deserving of its own sub-section. Despite only being 10 to 15 microns thick (one sixth the thickness of a piece of paper), it is the stratum corneum that presents the primary barrier to the skin, preventing external particles entering the skin, such as dust, microbes etc. This is composed of many layers of dead keratinocytes called corneocytes (or squames) that are continuously shed and replaced by cells from deeper layers. Desquamation is an extension of the word ‘squame’ which is the process of shedding dead cells from the outer layer of the skin and replacing them with new cells from deeper layers. Mechanical exfoliation with a product such as Purifying Facial Exfoliant Paste or Tea Tree Leaf Facial Exfoliant aids this process. [skincare_topic_photo image="696"][/skincare_topic_photo] Its impressive barrier properties are a result of its unique structure. Made up of flat cells called corneocytes, surrounded by a lipid matrix. The best way to think of the structure of the stratum corneum is to envisage a brick wall, with corneocytes being the bricks and skin lipids the mortar (cement). In order to function effectively, it is important to nourish both the ‘bricks’ and the ‘mortar’, with humectants and emollients, anti-oxidants and carefully selected efficacious botanicals.
  • To address dehydration we need to introduce water and/or molecules able to bind and trap water into the skin.
  • To address dryness we need to nourish the ‘mortar’ and the hydrolipidic film.
In order to do this, we can use emollients and humectants.

On a physiological level, skin is a responsive organism that reflects – and responds – to the environment. Cold weather reduces blood circulation. This reduces nutrients and water which is carried to the lowest layer of the skin, the dermis. Hot weather can also dehydrate, because we sweat to cool ourselves. What people also experience is increased oil production, and this combination of oil and sweat can lead to reactivity and irritation. What is challenging is balancing the need for thorough cleansing, and reduction of oil without over-stripping because the skin still needs hydration.

[skincare_topic_photo image="860"][/skincare_topic_photo]
The skin of infants (from birth to twelve-months-old) is fragile. It is thinner and the oil glands are less active. It is more sensitive to UV radiation, dehydration and dryness.
We believe the treatment and nurturing of infant skin is a vital part of baby care. In our view, infants need only be bathed in tepid water with the addition of organically grown black tea (the tannins in tea are sufficient to cleanse delicate skin). A few drops of organic olive oil massaged into the scalp and bodies of infants after bathing is sufficient to hydrate infant skin.
After twelve months of age we recommend a few drops of our Geranium Leaf Body Cleanser be added to bath water followed by a small amount of Geranium Leaf Hydrating Body Treatment, blended with olive oil, for massaging into the body after bathing.
Skin and the Poetics of Time

Artificial air and temperature controlled conditions (air conditioning and heating) compromise the skin’s protective moisture barrier, causing it to dehydrate, becoming sensitive or reactive.
Here we are thinking about continued time spent in office environments, air travel, or working and sleeping in climate controlled buildings.
Prolonged time in air-conditioned environments, whether the temperature is moderated to be warmer or cooler, can dehydrate the skin.

Oxidation is the chemical combination of a substance with oxygen. This occurs every day as part of our metabolic functioning and plays an important role in overall health.
However, the process of oxidation also unleashes free radicals (essentially, unstable molecules), which can damage the healthy cells they come into contact with.
When a free radical is within the skin it will try to rebalance its lack, or excess, of electrons by interacting with other molecules. It is this interaction, sometimes with the wrong molecule, that causes problems and which anti-oxidants set to remedy.
When free radicals are more numerous than the natural anti-oxidants in the skin it sets up a situation called 'oxidative-stress'.
In some respects, oxygen is a paradox. We require it to function, yet in some instances in can be deleterious. During natural respiration and production of energy our bodies create the ominous sounding ‘Reactive Oxygen Species.’ Our skin has a natural defence system to fight these, made up of enzymes and other anti-oxidant components such as ascorbic acid, beta-carotene and so on.
But this natural defence will become overwhelmed if the onslaught from free radicals is too high. It is all about the balance between ‘oxidant’ and ‘anti-oxidant’.
[skincare_topic_photo image="995"][/skincare_topic_photo]

Free radicals occur in greater numbers after the skin is exposed to UVA and UVB rays, pollution or when the skin experiences minor trauma. Our susceptibility to them is heightened if we are stressed, smoke, eat poorly or don't allow ourselves sufficient rest. If left unchecked, free radicals can cause healthy cells to mutate or degenerate, and key structural proteins such as collagen and elastin won't form properly.
Ultimately this can lead to either barrier disruption, reactivity or sensitivity, over-production of skin cells (flaking, dulling, and irritation) or most seriously of all, skin cancer.
Damaged skin cells as a result of free radical damage can also manifest as wrinkles, pigmentation and general 'ageing'.

[skincare_topic_photo image="998"][/skincare_topic_photo] [skincare_topic_photo image="999"][/skincare_topic_photo] [skincare_topic_photo image="1000"][/skincare_topic_photo] Anti-oxidants are substances that inhibit oxidation. They are found in a variety of foods, and bring health benefits by neutralising free radicals. Polyphenolic anti-oxidants are found in coffee, chocolate, red wine, soy, oregano and olive oil; flavonoids in tea, citrus fruit, onion and apple; and lycopene in tomato and grapefruit. Anti-oxidants in tablet form have been shown to be less effective than those consumed as part of a balanced diet. Accordingly, we recommend a hearty intake of fruits and vegetables, washed down with a sensible amount of red wine. Anti-oxidants may also provide protection when applied topically. A common analogy, and one we all remember from our initial three-day training at Aesop, is that of a slice of apple rubbed with lemon juice. Left unprotected, the apple will quickly turn brown as it oxidises; however, the lemon juice (rich in Vitamin C) slows this process noticeably. Applying anti-oxidants to the skin has a similar effect and hence our commitment to using such ingredients. The process of oxidation occurs in our bodies as part of everyday metabolic functioning. However as part of a total wellbeing approach to health we try to minimise the introduction of additional free radicals which can lead to excessive oxidation. The term 'anti-oxidant' in a skin-care context refers to an agent that stops or decreases the speed of oxidation. Parsley Seed Oil, Vitamin E (Tocopherol) and Stabilised Vitamin C (Sodium Ascorbyl Phosphate and Magnesium Ascorbyl Phosphate) are anti-oxidants that can be effectively incorporated into skin care products used to ‘quench’ and ‘scavenge’ free radicals. They work by impeding further damage and even assisting in restoring skin cells to their normal, healthy state.

A lack of vitamins in the body can leave the skin looking dull, lifeless and blotchy. Oral intake, along with topical application of vitamins is essential to maintaining healthy skin and counter the effects of skin in flux. All Aesop formulations contain vitamins in some form or other. Those used in the Skincare+ range, and therefore the ones we speak about most often are as follows;
  • Vitamin A
Adequate levels of vitamin A are essential in maintaining skin integrity and the skin’s barrier function, which helps to protect against the entry of foreign particles, and improves hydration as a result of reduced water loss. In vitamin A deficiency, cells lose their ability to differentiate properly, impairing skin integrity and elasticity. Many of our products contain Beta Carotene, a precursor of Vitamin A which is enzymatically converted by the body into vitamin A.
  • Vitamin B3
We utilise Niacinamide, the water soluble amide form of skin strengthening Vitamin B3, which is an excellent moisturiser that soothes irritated and inflamed skin.
  • Pro-Vitamin B5
D-panthenol is the pro-vitamin of pantothenic acid, vitamin B5. The term pro-vitamin refers to the way in which panthenol is metabolised in the skin to pantothenic acid. As an emollient and moisturiser it makes skin softer and more elastic. Pantothenic acid also soothes irritated and inflamed skin, thanks to its anti-inflammatory properties.
  • Vitamin C
Ascorbic Acid (vitamin C) has important physiological effects including the inhibition of melanin production, promotion of collagen synthesis and prevention of free radical formation. In turn, these processes assist in preserving the skin’s elasticity, maintaining an even skin tone by minimising discolouration, and reducing skin cell damage as a result of reactive oxygen species found in the atmosphere, known as free radicals. We utilise stabilised forms of vitamin C, Magnesium Ascorbyl Phosphate and Sodium Ascorbyl Phosphate, to ensure positive effects on the skin. Both these derivatives are easily converted to ascorbic acid in the skin by internal enzymes, whereby vitamin C can elicit its effect.
  • Vitamin E
Vitamin E is an excellent moisturiser, offering exceptional skin conditioning properties and a potent anti-oxidant, with free -tocopherol being the most biologically active form. When applied topically, vitamin E can help protect the skin from free radical damage, the process responsible for ageing the skin’s outward appearance. Used in combination with vitamin C, it works synergistically to protect the skin from sun damage.

The first half of this Chapter was dedicated to the skin and time. Now we will begin the second half, in which we look at one of the major factors which impact on how the health of the skin can be compromised in both the short and long term – sun exposure.
The way the outdoors impacts upon the skin is a vitally important matter which needs to be considered throughout the life of our skin.
Exposure: UV Radiation and the Skin

[skincare_topic_photo image="662"][/skincare_topic_photo]
The Aesop approach to mature skin is to hydrate and protect the skin to ensure it is healthy and looking its best. We are reluctant to engage in conversations about filling wrinkles and reversing the signs of ageing, however hope these passages of information, dissecting how the skin ages over time, will compound our philosophy with rational facts. We do not wish to be aloof or ignorant to the topic of ‘ageing’, or to address clients’ needs with insensitivity. Our preference is to simply look at preventing further damage rather than turning back time, a feat we believe cannot come from any jar.
One of the main concerns many have about 'ageing' and the impact of this process on the skin is wrinkles. Wrinkling happens when the protein elastin in the elastic tissue of the dermis loses its resiliency. This causes the dermis to become more closely bound to the underlying tissue. Also, the layer of fat beneath our skin diminishes, causing the skin to sag into wrinkles. The wrinkling process is reinforced because an adult’s ageing epidermis does not produce new cells as readily as it did during childhood and adolescence. The epidermal cells are simply not as vital as they used to be.
Exposure to the ultraviolet rays in sunlight speeds up the wrinkling process, causing the collagen and elastin in the dermis to degenerate. As a result, the skin becomes slack (loses suppleness) and prematurely aged.
To begin this chapter, we will summarise the changes our skin is subject to as we grow older, beginning with infancy.
Skin and the Poetics of Time

[skincare_topic_photo image="902"][/skincare_topic_photo] Within the sub layers of the epidermis, there are four major types of cells. For the purposes of discussing skin care with our customers, It is unnecessary to go into great detail here. However, it proves instructive to understand the different functions of just a few of these cells, and how they eventually impact on the appearance and health of the skin. The only two types of cells which are generally discussed in skin care are: Keratinocytes – These make up 90 per cent of the cells in the epidermis. These cells produce keratin, which is a tough fibrous protein that provides protection. Melanocytes – Produce the pigment melanin that protects against damage by ultraviolent radiation and give colour to the skin. The melanin is our first UV filter.

The dermis is a strong, highly flexible and resilient connective tissue meshwork consisting of:

-   tough collagenous fibres -   supportive reticular fibres -   flexible elastic fibres

The dermis functions as:
  1. An overall foundation structure for the epidermis (and is vital for its survival)
  2. The major site of blood vessels, nerves and lymphatic vessels in the skin
The dermis also protects the skin against trauma, and accounts for over 90 per cent of skin mass. It varies across the body in both thickness and composition, and is generally thicker in males than females. This is a result of males having higher circulating levels of testosterone. The dermis also thins and is more prone to breakdown with age. Unlike the epidermis, the dermis contains very few cells. It is composed of connective tissue containing collagen and elastin fibres.

The Dermis is divided into two Layers.

  1. The Papillary Layer is the thin, upper layer directly connected to the epidermis.
  2. The Reticular Layer is the lower layer of the dermis, and contains thick collagen bundles and fine elastin fibres. This layer carries most of the physical stress of the skin.
In the context of our products and skin care in general, the elements of the dermis which are discussed most often are collagen and elastin. [skincare_topic_photo image="830"]This photomicrograph shows the principal fibres that limit movement and stabilize the body's shape. The diagonal line sweeping down to the right is a single pre-collagen unit. The snaking one is elastin, and the thin cobweb-like fibres are reticulin.[/skincare_topic_photo]

Did you know?

Hand and foot prints are formed by what are called the papillary ridges, or friction ridges of the epidermis, that are specifically determined by the underlying structure of the dermis. These patterns are unique for each of us and do not change throughout life, and in the case of fingerprints, have become an effective means of identification.

Did you know?

Tattoo dyes are injected into the dermis, where the dyed cells do not move outward toward the surface as the skin is shed and replaced. In the same way, scars and stretch marks do not disappear easily because they involve the dermis.

1. COLLAGEN

[skincare_topic_photo image="702"][/skincare_topic_photo] The word collagen is derived from the Greek words kolla, meaning ‘glue’ and gennan, ‘to produce.’ It has a number of functions, but chief among these is its role in providing strength. The ability of collagen to do this is affected by both age and sun damage. Collagen is key to skin strength and firmness. It is also the main structural protein in the skin, helping keep skin firm. When in abundance it confers a smooth appearance to the skin. Collagen is the primary component of all connective tissues, and can thus be considered the body’s most important structural protein. Vitamin C is involved in almost every stage in collagen synthesis, emphasising the importance of this ingredient in our Skin Care + products. The process of collagen synthesis is complex, but what is essential to know is that without vitamin C the formation of collagen would not be able to take place. Not only does vitamin C assist with collagen synthesis, it increases the proliferation of fibroblasts. A combination of more fibroblasts, plus an overall increase in collagen synthesis by the fibroblasts, leads to overall improvement in skin firmness, elasticity and perhaps crucially – barrier integrity.

2. ELASTIN

Elastin is a fibrous protein with a spiral-like molecular structure that gives the skin its resiliency and elasticity. The elastin and collagen interwoven within the dermis provide for the elasticity, resistance, softness, and suppleness of the epidermis. Elastin undergoes a continual degradation, and two of the most common physical manifestations of this occur with ageing and sun damage. One of the most marked signs of photo-ageing (sun spots/pigment aside) is pronounced thickening of the skin (called solar elastosis). Note that as well as acting on collagen production, vitamin C also inhibits elastin synthesis. It therefore goes some way to decrease and prevent solar elastosis. Within the dermis as a whole: elastin density is greatest in the upper, papillary layer. The concentration or density of collagen is greatest in the lower, reticular layer. This combination of actions on both collagen and elastin are what render vitamin C rich formulations so valuable for skin care. We obtain vitamin C solely from our diet, but because of its rapid absorption and excretion, even taking large doses orally will not significantly affect the levels of vitamin C within the skin. Further to this, exposure to UV light and pollutants in the air can significantly deplete vitamin C stores in the skin by as much as 50%. [skincare_topic_photo image="683"][/skincare_topic_photo] It is for this reason that topical application is important, and why meaningful doses of vitamin C delivered via products such as Perfect Facial Hydrating Cream, B Triple C Facial Balancing Gel and  Lucent Facial Concentrate offers additional benefits to the skin. [skincare_topic_photo image="676"][/skincare_topic_photo]

The hypodermis is the third layer of the skin, and also the thickest. It is sometimes also referred to as the subcutaneous tissue or subcutis. This is an underlying, or supportive layer that includes greater concentrations of fat cells and tissue. These fat cells are largely responsible for body contours and other padding, as found in the heels and the breasts. The subcutaneous tissue is attached to the dermis by collagen and elastin, and is primarily made up of cells called adipocytes, which are specialised cells that store fat. Blood vessels and lymph nodes are also distributed throughout the subcutaneous tissue. This region of the skin also houses the bases of the hair follicles and the coiled ducts of the sweat glands. The main roles of the hypodermis are therefore:
  1. As an energy reserve - fat is an efficient means of storing up energy which can be released and put back into the circulatory system during periods of exertion, famine, or lack of energy.
  2. Providing thermal insulation: the subcutaneous layer of adipose tissue helps keep the body warm. In this way it can be considered to be working as a passively as a thermoregulator.

[skincare_topic_photo image="832"]Sylvia Plath, poet and author, in her late twenties, note the character showing in the skin around the eyes.[/skincare_topic_photo]
From the age of twenty-five to thirty, the epidermis becomes thinner. On average, elastin and collagen production decrease at a rate of about one per cent each year. The exact time of this change depends on our genes, lifestyle and environmental exposure.
The skin starts to wrinkle in areas of the greatest facial expression: around the eyes, mouth, and brow. The familiar “crow’s feet,” lines radiating from the corner of each eye.
This is when the topical application of vitamin C becomes relevant as this increases fibroblast proliferation (this concept was introduced in Chapter One), which in turn increases collagen production and products from the Skin Care+ range, namely B Triple C Facial Balancing Gel, Lucent Facial Concentrate and Perfect Facial Hydrating Cream become important and should be integrated as a twice weekly treatment.
Pronounced changes occur in the epidermis and the dermis during from the ages of thirty to forty. New lines on the skin typically appear between the eyebrows and in front of the ears.
Skin and the Poetics of Time

For women, the hormonal changes in the years leading up to, and then following the menopause, have a significant effect upon the skin. Menopause, the cessation of menstruation, begins to exert its effect as early as the mid to late thirties (during peri-menopause - the time before full menopause), though generally speaking true menopause occurs between the ages of forty-five to fifty.
Oestrogen levels decrease faster than testosterone and this imbalance can result in a resurgence of hormonal breakouts, as testosterone exerts its oil increasing effect. Reduced turnover of skin, and gradual decline in collagen production can also lead to clogged pores., but unlike hormonal outbreaks earlier in life, breakouts in later adulthood tend to manifest as smaller much more localised red spots, bumps and blemishes. To assist with the turnover of skin, twice weekly exfoliation with either Tea Tree Leaf Exfoliant or Purifying Facial Cream Cleanser, and daily cleansing with Parsley Seed Face Cleanser, which contains Lactic Acid, are recommended.
Because of oestrogen's strong effect upon collagen, elastin and natural moisturising factors, the skin begins to lose some of its strength and suppleness, and there is need for greater levels of hydration to combat increased tendency to dryness. Richer formulations, particularly those that help boost the levels of supportive collagen – such as Perfect Facial Hydrating Cream – will have greater relevance during this phase of life and should be used daily.
In the lead up to the onset of menopause testosterone levels finally drop in the same way as oestrogen. This levelling of the hormones marks the end of the propensity to breakouts and acne, but brings with it thinner skin that may as a result be more prone to sensitivity and reactivity. Nourishing, gentle and non-disruptive formulations such as Parsley Seed Anti-Oxidant Facial Hydrating Cream and Elemental Facial Barrier Cream come to the fore, along with skin nurturing facial oils such as Damascan Rose Facial Treatment.
Skin and the Poetics of Time

[skincare_topic_photo image="683"]Elemental Facial Barrier Cream[/skincare_topic_photo]
[skincare_topic_photo image="674"]Damascan Rose Facial Treatment[/skincare_topic_photo]
The epidermis becomes thinner and the barrier less robust. This reduced barrier function causes redness and dryness to become more frequent, and hyperpigmentation may appear in different areas.
Within the dermis, connective tissue starts to lose structure, as well as the ability to retain water. This is when products such as Blue Chamomile Facial Hydrating Masque and our Skin Care+ range come to the fore. There is also a further reduction in collagen and elastin production. Reduced blood flow results in a loss of brightness in the skin.
For this reason, we recommend the following products during this time period.
New wrinkles appear on the upper lip in the sixties and seventies, and all of the established wrinkles become more pronounced. During this time there will be a reduction in lipid production and reduced synthesis of Hyaluronic Acid leading to dryness and dehydration. Our skin becomes more sensitive to UV radiation and there will often be increased hyperpigmentation, or age spots, beginning to appear.
We encourage all in this age to enforce a continued use of sunscreen to prevent further damage from UV radiation. Couple this with a liberal use of vitamin C rich products, Perfect Facial Hydrating Cream (rich in both vitamins and hydration), to both assist with maintaining suppleness and barrier support, and also to help balance, tone, and reduce or minimise the appearance of highly pigmented areas.
This is also a period of life in which richly nourishing and highly emollient products (to help guard against oxidative damage to barrier lipids) such as Parsley Seed Facial Hydrating Cream, Perfect Facial Hydrating Cream or Elemental Facial Barrier Cream offer significant benefit, particularly when blended with emollient boosting oils such as Damascan Rose Facial Treatment and Parsley Seed Anti-Oxidant Facial Treatment.
[skincare_topic_photo image="676"]Perfect Facial Hydrating Cream[/skincare_topic_photo]
Skin and the Poetics of Time
Exposure: UV Radiation and the Skin

[skincare_topic_photo image="664"][/skincare_topic_photo]
Ultra-Violet rays (UV) are wavelengths with differing energies. Everyone during their daily life is exposed to UV radiation from the sun. The more energetic the ray, the greater the chance of them damaging the skin.
There are three types of UV rays; UVA, UVB, UVC.
UVA rays penetrate the most deeply, reaching the dermis. They work to damage collagen and elastin, and are primarily responsible for photo-ageing (think UVA for ageing). Although not painful, this is what causes coarse wrinkles, leathery skin, sagging and brown pigmentation.
UVB rays are biologically active however cannot penetrate beyond the epidermis of the skin, they are responsible for sun burn (think UVB for burning) and a number of damaging photochemical changes within cells, leading to premalignant and malignant changes.
UVC rays are the most damaging, however as sunlight passes through the atmosphere, all UVC and approximately 90% of UVB radiation is absorbed by ozone, water vapour, oxygen and carbon dioxide.
UVA radiation is less affected by the atmosphere. For this reason the UV radiation reaching the Earth’s surface is largely composed of mostly UVA with a smaller amount of UVB.
UVA rays also exacerbate the carcinogenic effects of UVB rays, and increasingly are being seen as a cause of skin cancer on their own. It is for this reason that any sunscreen product should ideally protect against both UVA and UVB rays.
Exposure: UV Radiation and the Skin

[skincare_topic_photo image="959"][/skincare_topic_photo] A note about SPF and the protection each product offers: The SPF number represents a sun protection factor. This is determined by measuring the time it takes to produce the first signs of sunburn (reddening) in the presence of sunscreen compared with unprotected skin. If protected skin takes 15 times longer to show reddening than unprotected skin then the product is allocated a SPF of 15. SPF is a measure of UVB protection as this is the sun radiation which is responsible for the visible effects of sunburn – reddening and blistering. However UVA protection is equally important as this is the main contributor to premature skin ageing. Each of our sunscreen products has met this standard as well as those set down by the various regulatory agencies in the markets in which we operate. In terms of how much UV is filtered:
  • SPF 15 filters out approximately 93 percent of all incoming UVB rays.
  • SPF 30 keeps out 97 percent.
  • SPF 50 keeps out 98 percent.
Exposure: UV Radiation and the Skin

[skincare_topic_photo image="962"][/skincare_topic_photo] When exposed to the sun, skin produces its own sunscreen, Melanin. Melanin is produced by Melanocytes in the epidermis and is the origin of the skin's colour. When our Melanin levels rise this is what we know as a 'tan. These cells produce a dark brown pigment called melanin, which becomes distributed throughout the epidermis and gives skin its characteristic colouration. There are two types of melanin that determine skin (and hair) colour:
  1. Pheomelanin (or red melanin) found in those with lighter skin, and
  2. Eumelanin (black and dark brown melanin), found in those with darker skin.
Skin colour is determined by the amount and type of melanin in the skin, and variation is largely due to genetics.

item.title: Why does skin need sun protection?
item.dc:creator: sc-admin

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Exposure: UV Radiation and the Skin
Why does skin need sun protection?

Sunshine, below sunburn level, can be good for us, allowing the body to create vitamin D needed for health and wellbeing.
However, in most cases we vastly overdo our sun exposure leading to a range of skin problems, from less serious but nonetheless painful sunburn, through to the much graver skin cancer. Other summer skin problems include photosensitive rashes and prickly heat. In addition, sun exposure can worsen already existing conditions like rosacea and hyperpigmentation (darkening of the skin caused by excess melanin).
For this reason, skin should be protected all year round with a sunscreen product, although between 10am – 4pm in summer the risk of damage from UV radiation is at its greatest. We aim to deliver highly effective broad spectrum protection, from formulations with refined and elegant skin feel. Our sunscreens offer not only protection from UVA and UVB rays, but also offer additional benefits to the skin such as hydration or anti-oxidant protection.
To complement the use of sunscreen products we also recommend use of protective clothing, sunglasses and sun hats. It is important to remember to reapply sunscreen products more frequently when near reflective surfaces such as water, sand and snow. These are things that many of us learned in school, but tend to conveniently forget as we get older.
Exposure: UV Radiation and the Skin

[skincare_topic_photo image="968"]The above image is of a 69 year old truck driver exposed to UVA over the course of many years through his truck window. Note that there appears to be accelerated ageing on just one side of the face. This perfectly demonstrates how UVA rays are not filtered by glass (Source: The New England Journal of Medicine ©2012).[/skincare_topic_photo]
Anyone over the age of six months should ideally use a sunscreen every day, or during periods of exposure. Even those who work inside are exposed to ultraviolet radiation for brief periods throughout the day, and this holds even truer if they work near windows, which filter out UVB but not UVA rays.
Children under the age of six months should not be exposed to the sun, because their skin is much more sensitive to the sun's rays and may also sensitive to the ingredients in chemical-based sunscreen (i.e. those containing chemical UV filters). Shade and protective clothing are the best ways to protect infants from the sun.
For both adults and children alike, sunscreens should not be used as an alternative to clothing and shade, but instead be viewed as an additional means of protection.
Exposure: UV Radiation and the Skin

The SPF (solar or sun protection factor) in sunscreen refers to its ability to protect against the burning rays of UVB radiation. UVA accounts for 95% of sunlight that reaches the earth, and so the methods and symbols used on labels to indicate UVA protection vary around the globe. For a global skin care brand, this can at times be vexing as there are currently no globally agreed upon standards to measure protection against UVA. Considering the geographical worldliness of modern life and a customers, a background of the current ratings can be summarised as follows: Asia: In some Asian countries a PA rating system is used to indicate UVA protection factor. The scale ranges from PA+ to PA++++ as follows: PA+ denotes a sunscreen with a PPD of 2 to less than 4. PA++ one with PPD of 4 to 8, PA+++ from 8 to 16. PA++++ those with a PPD of 16 or greater. The higher the PA rating, the higher the level of protection offered. Australia / New Zealand: Use of the term 'Broad Spectrum' indicates compliance with Australian regulatory standards for UVA protection. The UVA protection for a sunscreen should be at least a third of the labelled SPF. Brazil: UVA protection is designated by 'FPUVA'. Similar to Australia and the EU Regulation, the UVA protection for a sunscreen should be at least a third of the labelled SPF. Europe: According to the EU Regulation, the UVA protection for a sunscreen should be at least a third of the labelled SPF and 90% of the total UV absorption must fall under 370 nm. A product that achieves this requirement will be labelled with a UVA logo, the letters 'UVA' printed in a circle. US and Canada: Use of the term 'Broad Spectrum' indicates compliance with regulatory standards for UVA protection. To achieve a broad spectrum rating, 90% of the total UV absorption must fall under 370 nm and as a result that a product offers an appropriate level of protection from UVA.

What do our three SPF products protect against, and how?

There are two classes of sunscreen agents which are distinguished by their mode of action. Inorganic agents (physical blockers) are ingredients which form a protective layer on the skin and absorb UV radiation. They are known as inorganic ingredients because they are mineral salts, such as Zinc Oxide or Titanium Dioxide. They are ideal sunscreen agents as they provide protection over a broad UV range (UVA and UVB). This is the way in which Sage and Zinc Facial Hydrating Cream – SPF15 works. Organic agents (chemical sunscreen agents) are ingredients which are chemically altered when they absorb UV radiation energy. Due to this mechanism of action each ingredient is only effective over a narrow UV range and therefore a combination of ingredients must be used to provide broad spectrum protection. Protective Body Lotion SPF50 (Avail Body Lotion with Sunscreen in the US and Japan) has been formulated with a combination of chemical filters to achieve high-level protection, as well as skin-nourishing Vitamin E to lightly hydrate. High-level SPF protection is relevant during periods of greater UV exposure, i.e. during summer (beach) and all-year round for outdoor activities (particular year-round relevance in AU / NZ / SG / MY/ LA / Miami).

A note on Protective Lip Balm SPF 30 (Avail Lip Balm with Sunscreen in the US and Japan)

[skincare_topic_photo image="971"]Protective Body Lotion SPF50 - Protective Lip Balm[/skincare_topic_photo] Contains a blend of both inorganic and organic UV filters to achieve broad spectrum protection against UVA and UVB. The Lip Balm's richly emollient base nourishes and protects the lips. The ‘double protection’ provided makes this product suitable for use in all climates and seasons. The SPF protection will be relevant during periods of greater UV exposure and the residual barrier left on the lips locks in moisture and guards against damage from the elements.

In this third and final chapter, we will consolidate the foundational learning from the previous two chapters, and consider the skin as it is when it is subject to change, or more simply, in flux.
Our intent is to make the learning offered useful to the store environment, and to address many of the topics our customers ask of us every day. How does seasonal change affect my skin? What role do topically applied vitamins play in protecting the skin? This Chapter will address these questions, as well as delving more deeply into free radicals and anti-oxidants.
At Aesop the concept of seasonal change is central to the way we prescribe skin care, but why?

item.title: How does where we live impact on the sun damage we are exposed to?
item.dc:creator: sc-admin

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Even though we addressed UV and the skin in Chapter Two, for the purposes of this chapter and relating it to seasonal change, there are environmental considerations also. Key among these are;
  1. Sun height: the higher the sun in the sky, the higher the UV radiation level. Therefore UV radiation varies with time of day and time of year, with maximum levels occurring when the sun is at its maximum elevation, at around midday (solar noon) during the summer months.
  2. Latitude: the closer to the equator, the higher the UV radiation levels. This means regions closer to the Equator will have a higher propensity to UV damage. Considering Aesop customers, this translates to those from Brazil, but also Australia and South East Asia.
  3. Cloud cover: UV radiation levels are highest under cloudless skies. Even with cloud cover, UV radiation levels can be high as a result of the scattering of UV radiation by water molecules and fine particles in the atmosphere. This is why sunburn still occurs on cloudy days.
  4. Altitude: at higher altitudes, a thinner atmosphere filters less UV radiation. For every 1000 metre increase in altitude, UV levels increase by 10% to 12%.
  5. Ozone level: ozone absorbs some of the UV radiation that would otherwise reach the Earth’s surface. Ozone levels vary over the year and even across the day.
  6. Ground reflection: UV radiation is reflected or scattered to varying extents by different surfaces, e.g. snow can reflect as much as 80% of UV radiation, dry beach sand about 15%, and sea foam about 25%.

item.title: What is the difference between dry and dehydrated skin?
item.dc:creator: sc-admin

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
[skincare_topic_photo image="674"][/skincare_topic_photo] Having ‘dry’ skin is different to having 'dehydrated' skin – even though many of us use the terms interchangeably. Dry skin is a lack of oil (or sebum), whereas dehydrated skin means a lack of water or moisture. This may seem counter-intuitive, but if we think about oily skin, it can be dehydrated, but not dry. Dryness of the skin may induce dehydration, because greater water is lost, but the opposite of this is not true; dehydrated skin will not cause dryness. Dry skin can lead to sensitivities because the skin is not as well protected (the barrier is compromised) which can lead to sensitivity and general sense of reactivity also. To distinguish, the symptoms of dry skin may include;
  • Scaliness or flaking
  • Rigidity or roughness,
  • A sensation of 'tightness' or discomfort
Dehydrated skin may be more noticeable than dry skin, presenting as a complexion which may be duller, wrinkles will be more apparent and the skin may be thinner. Reasons for Dehydration [skincare_topic_photo image="676"][/skincare_topic_photo] The reasons for dehydration in the skin can be complex, but can be simplified by re-visiting the concept of Trans-Epidermal Water Loss (TEWL). If skin is dehydrated, it is a result of too great a loss of water from within. Because dehydrated skin is lacking in moisture, the approach to remedy it must have both an internal and topical focus. Internally, we advocate an increase in the consumption of water and omega rich foods. Topically we insist on generous doses of hydration delivered from aqueous formulations such as toners and Aloe Vera based serums, or by increasing the skin's inherent hydration level through regular use of formulations containing hydration boosting Sodium Carrageenan (Blue Chamomile Facial Hydrating Masque and Lucent Facial Concentrate).

item.title: Exfoliating mature skin – should we, or shouldn’t we?
item.dc:creator: sc-admin

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Exfoliating mature skin – should we, or shouldn’t we?

[skincare_topic_photo image="1027"]Parsley Seed Facial Cleanser[/skincare_topic_photo]
As we reach the age of sixty and above, there are certain risks associated with over-exfoliating. Our skin cell turnover slows, the skin is now thinner, and a reduced lipid content means overdoing it with exfoliating products can set the skin to increased sensitivity.
However, there is still a sound rationale for the use of ‘soft’ chemical exfoliants such as Lactic Acid. Using this ingredient – it can be found in Parsley Seed Facial Cleanser – can maintain a ‘brightness’ to the skin, as the slow turnover can manifest as skin which appears dull.
